title: Maslate
author: Maslate
content: As of now, they've accumulated 924,768 BTC, while it's said that Satoshi holds around 1 million. So if they ever surpass Satoshi’s holdings, how might this affect the Bitcoin market? And if this trend continues, are institutional investors starting to take control?What could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?

comments.author: _act_
comments.body: Satoshi bitcoin holding is dormant. It should not be discussed with anything like ETF because there is no nothing ETF can be linked with it to have effect on the market. Discuss about ETF separately and also discuss about Satoshi bitcoin holding separately.Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMWhat could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?It only means more adoption and better tomorrow.

comments.author: Helena Yu
comments.body: Nothing, surpassing Satoshi's holdings doesn't mean they already able to control Bitcoin, because centralized exchanges own 2.3 Million of Bitcoin, yet we don't see any big change even they've accumulated more than Satoshi.A big problem will happen in the future if US spot Bitcoin ETF report they've accumulated more than 21 Million Bitcoin. Even though we know it's impossible since the max cap is 21 Million, but they can create fake news if they've accumulated most of Bitcoin. There's no proof in on-chain if they've accumulated these numbers.

comments.author: aoluain
comments.body: Thats a wild comparison to make. There is no relation between Satoshi's holding and any other holding. It doesnt matter! I hold more Bitcoin than somepeople and there are others who own more than me.Its guite something that the spot ETF's have already been able to accumulate almost1,000,000 Bitcoin. As demand increases so too will their holding. Its kind of inevitablethat they could/will become the biggest holders of Bitcoin. Question then arises as to what happens if they hold 50% of the total supply?

comments.author: HeRetiK
comments.body: Quote from: Helena Yu on October 10, 2024, 08:58:08 AMA big problem will happen in the future if US spot Bitcoin ETF report they've accumulated more than 21 Million Bitcoin. Even though we know it's impossible since the max cap is 21 Million, but they can create fake news if they've accumulated most of Bitcoin. There's no proof in on-chain if they've accumulated these numbers.Depending on how the industry develops I'd expect some sort of Proof of Reserves procedure to become standard after a while, similar to what CEXes have already begun doing. Technically it shouldn't be an issue and I believe legally they are obliged to have outstanding shares reflected 1:1 in their Bitcoin reserves.I'm not saying to trust ETFs, just saying that they can and should be held accountable to avoid any bookkeeping shenanigans in the future.Quote from: aoluain on October 10, 2024, 09:15:42 AMQuestion then arises as to what happens if they hold 50% of the total supply?Regulatory capture. There's a non-zero chance that attempts will be made to make self-custody coins less attractive than ETF shares by pushing self-custody ever more into a legal grey area.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Quote from: Helena Yu on October 10, 2024, 08:58:08 AMNothing, surpassing Satoshi's holdings doesn't mean they already able to control Bitcoin, because centralized exchanges own 2.3 Million of Bitcoin, yet we don't see any big change even they've accumulated more than Satoshi.A big problem will happen in the future if US spot Bitcoin ETF report they've accumulated more than 21 Million Bitcoin. Even though we know it's impossible since the max cap is 21 Million, but they can create fake news if they've accumulated most of Bitcoin. There's no proof in on-chain if they've accumulated these numbers. that would be a funny joke because Bitcoin Cap is not even up to 21 Million in supply So even if they do get all the Bitcoin in the world including lost and not yet mined they can never have more or even up-to 21 million Bitcoin. The Pros is that Bitcoin becomes more legitimate in the eyes of the public and Would kinda reduce the psychological impact of satoshi having up-to 1 million BTC (doubt it's up-to) to some individuals who fear it's movement.But it still wouldn't change anything since CEX are holding more than Satoshi did. The Cons Would be it would get more expensive to get a Bitcoin in the future for new entrants if they do continue to accumulate more Price centralization, in the sense that they could manipulate price and any news of them selling would affect the market in a short term.Quote from: _act_ on October 10, 2024, 08:15:37 AMIt only means more adoption and better tomorrow.  I'm not against it and even believe it's bound to happen anytime soon with the rate they buyingAnd could be considered a plus to Bitcoin price and adoption but call me a pessimist, I don't really see how that's a better tomorrow though. Yes more adoption but at what cost?

comments.author: icalical
comments.body: I don't think the ETF holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi's wallet has any significant effect toward Bitcoin market, however this trend that institutions are gaining influence, I think it's not fully bad news. Increased institutional interest might add a good deal of legitimacy and stability to Bitcoin, and maybe lead the prices to go up due to the increased demand, especially from institution.But I believe many people including me has this same concern, if most of Bitcoin were held by institution, then that creates centralization of control over something that is supposed to be decentralized, hence making Bitcoin no different from any other traditional financial asset. This may impede Bitcoin's functionality as a means of exchange in peer-to-peer transactions because, if major holders decide to sell, this may increase volatility. I think those centralized threat can be reduced if the community the retail holder of Bitcoin want to hold as much as Bitcoin as they can.

comments.author: Moreno233
comments.body: Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMAs of now, they've accumulated 924,768 BTC, while it's said that Satoshi holds around 1 million. So if they ever surpass Satoshi’s holdings, how might this affect the Bitcoin market? And if this trend continues, are institutional investors starting to take control?What could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?Nothing will change as long as Satoshi's Bitcoin remains the way they are. Satoshi have not moved the coins in the wallets that we can directly link to him so those Bitcoin have no significant impact on the market and the Bitcoin ecosystem in general. So, until those coins are moved, the market will treat them as if they were burnt so irrespective of the quantity of Bitcoin held by another whale, Satoshi's holding will not impact the market in any single way rather the market will always respond to the forces of demand and supply as it does now. I know there have been several rumors about the identity of Satoshi which I don't know if that would lead to anything. Whatever happens, until the coins in those wallets are moved, nothing changes.

comments.author: hd49728
comments.body: Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMAs of now, they've accumulated 924,768 BTC, while it's said that Satoshi holds around 1 million.The figure for BTC owns by Satoshi Nakamoto is the estimation that is based on earlier used addresses that assumed to be Satoshi Nakamoto's addresses.Who owns the most bitcoinsQuoteSo if they ever surpass Satoshi’s holdings, how might this affect the Bitcoin market? And if this trend continues, are institutional investors starting to take control?What could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?First, it's important to point out that it's unnecessary to connect BTC held by Bitcoin Spot ETFs in the USA. with BTC supposed to own by Satoshi Nakamoto.Second, let's note another thing that Bitcoin Spot ETFs purchase and hold bitcoins on behalf of their customers, except bitcoins invested by their Bitcoin Spot ETF companies.So, they can not arbitrarily sell those bitcoins of their customers if there is no request of withdrawal from customers.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: I don't think you should compare the coins mined by Satoshi and those bought by companies like BlackRock or Fidelity - because Satoshi mined BTC because someone had to be the first to start the whole thing and it's obvious that he didn't do it for profit - while all these companies that buy BTC for their clients and their clients do it exclusively for profit and don't care about anything else at all.At some point, we will probably have a scenario when the majority of clients investing in BTC through spot ETFs will decide to sell - and then we might find out what it's like when someone dumps 1+ million BTC on the market.

comments.author: Swordsoffreedom
comments.body: Quote from: Ambatman on October 10, 2024, 09:27:23 AMQuote from: _act_ on October 10, 2024, 08:15:37 AMIt only means more adoption and better tomorrow.  I'm not against it and even believe it's bound to happen anytime soon with the rate they buyingAnd could be considered a plus to Bitcoin price and adoption but call me a pessimist, I don't really see how that's a better tomorrow though. Yes more adoption but at what cost? Bitcoin price will definitely increase but the price to pay could be very high, and the worst case scenario is that Bitcoin will become centralized with the majority of Bitcoin supply in their hands. This issue has been discussed and warned about a lot since the first days of bitcoin ETF approval, and that's also why some of us are against ETFs and Wall Street's involvement in the market. But at the end of the day, there is nothing we can do to stop them from interfering in the market because bitcoin is a free market and for everyone. The only thing we can do is adapt to the market situation because there will be no better solution for us.

comments.author: fikrett
comments.body: Quote from: ABCbits on October 10, 2024, 10:31:09 AMThe obvious cons is more Bitcoin is in hands of centralized party.Yeah, and if they push for idea of a central reserve for it, the number will be even bigger The market wouldn't mind it, though, the consequences of such a venture are debatable and uncertain. Of course, there will be probably regulations put up for it.

comments.author: dimonstration
comments.body: Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMWhat could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?Institutions holdings is not their own Bitcoin. They are just holding the funds of their customers since they are custodians. They don’t have any influence to sell their holdings on their own so there’s nothing wrong if they accumulate huge amount since it’s owned by their customers.I view it as positive since many traditional investors are now trusting Bitcoin investment that’s why it keeps growing despite the current price. I’m sure Satoshi holdings is not worthy basis since the founder is not active for a long time. I’m not sure either if Satoshi will resurface due to potential legal issue depending on his citizenship.

comments.author: Richbased
comments.body: Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMWhat could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?The amount of Bitcoin Satoshi is holding does not matter, perhaps being the founder and creator of bitcoin doesn't mean he will hold the highest amount of bitcoin and since his BTC wallet is dormant means that new bitcoins won't enter the wallet again which means that the Spot bitcoin ETFs will surely surpass Satoshi holdings in the future so there's no cons if institutions hold more BTC than Satoshi instead it's a great advantage towards the development of bitcoins, but my question is what will happen to the bitcoins that Satoshi is holding if it remains dormant for so long without the original owner Satoshi accessing it?

comments.author: hd49728
comments.body: Quote from: Lucius on October 10, 2024, 10:41:14 AMI don't think you should compare the coins mined by Satoshi and those bought by companies like BlackRock or Fidelity - because Satoshi mined BTC because someone had to be the first to start the whole thing and it's obvious that he didn't do it for profit - while all these companies that buy BTC for their clients and their clients do it exclusively for profit and don't care about anything else at all.Clients of Bitcoin Spot ETFs only care about profit and they will sell their bitcoins through Bitcoin Spot ETFs in future. Because if they care more than profit, they will know that "It's not your private keys, it's not your bitcoins" and they will purchase and store bitcoins by themselves than relying on Bitcoin Spot ETFs and their custodian partners.QuoteAt some point, we will probably have a scenario when the majority of clients investing in BTC through spot ETFs will decide to sell - and then we might find out what it's like when someone dumps 1+ million BTC on the market.Well, it's different of sales from many investors than sale from a single holder but I don't know effects from a first case will be bigger or smaller than the second case. People perhaps will be more fearful with the second case because a single person can sell it all in short time while many investors will sell their bitcoins at different times and it can last several months in distribution phase.

So if they ever surpass Satoshi’s holdings, how might this affect the Bitcoin market? And if this trend continues, are institutional investors starting to take control?Bitcoin market value is not been determined by Satoshi holding capacity, its majorly on its demand and supply.Secondly, Satoshi holdings is not the same as the total number of bitcoin in circulation, we are talking about 21 million including those to be mined, why should we keep comparing Spot bitcoin ETF to bitcoin when they are not the same, one is financial assets and the other decentralized crypto (bitcoin), we have nothing to get scared of as long as all these doesn't matter in determining the performance for bitcoin market price or value, its only a challenge between Satoshi holding and spot bitcoin ETF and not the bitcoin network.Quote from: Maslate on October 10, 2024, 08:05:49 AMWhat could be the pros and cons if institutions end up holding more Bitcoin than Satoshi combined?Nothing, as long as they know what they are doing, Satoshi holding is not the same as the bitcoin network bitcoin in circulation.

comments.author: hd49728
